docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Airline pilots asked the Federal Aviation Agency yesterday to ban the carrying of prisoners on commercial airliners unless they are handcuffed and accompanied by an armed escort....
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Airline pilots asked the Federal Aviation Agency yesterday to ban the carrying of prisoners on commercial airliners unless they are handcuffed and accompanied by an armed escort.
docs.abstract: Pilots ask FAA to bar prisoners from commercial carriers unless they are handcuffed and have armed escort

headline.main: PILOTS ASK GUARD ON PRISON FLIGHTS; Ruling Asked to Ban Travel by Unescorted Convicts

docs.snippet: An American congressman who led the battle to keep tight sanctions on Libya said Monday night that he believed that Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had ''turned the corner'' in abandoning terrorism and illicit weapons and should be reward...
docs.lead_paragraph: An American congressman who led the battle to keep tight sanctions on Libya said Monday night that he believed that Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had ''turned the corner'' in abandoning terrorism and illicit weapons and should be rewarded with improved relations. Representative Tom Lantos, a California Democrat and the first of several members of Congress to meet with Colonel Qaddafi, called on the Bush administration to lift the ban on American travel to Libya as a first step in normalizing relations with Tripoli.
docs.abstract: Repr Tom Lantos, who led battle for sanctions against Libya, says he believes Col Muammar el-Qaddafi has turned corner in abandoning terrorism and illicit weapons and should be rewarded with improved US relations; calls for lifting of travel ban after meeting with Libyan leader, in which he urged Qaddafi to issue apology to families of 270 people who died in bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland (S)

headline.main: Congressman Says U.S. Should Lift Its Ban on Travel to Libya

docs.snippet: President Bush's allies in Congress quietly eliminated a widely supported provision easing restrictions on American travel to Cuba from a major appropriations bill to save him from embarrassment over his political designs in Florida, officials fro...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush's allies in Congress quietly eliminated a widely supported provision easing restrictions on American travel to Cuba from a major appropriations bill to save him from embarrassment over his political designs in Florida, officials from both parties said Wednesday evening. Leaders of a House-Senate conference committee removed the provision on Wednesday before the bill reached the president, who had threatened to veto any legislation that lifted sanctions against Cuba, the officials said.
docs.abstract: Widely supported provision that would ease restrictions on American travel to Cuba is quietly eliminated from major appropriations bill by Pres Bush's allies in Congress, hoping to save him from embarrassment over his political designs in Florida, where 80 percent of Cuban-Americans vote for him; Bush had threatened to veto any legislation that lifts sanctions against Cuba (M)

headline.main: Bush's Allies Plan to Block Effort to Ease Ban on Cuban Travel

docs.snippet: A group of 10 Americans, ignoring warnings from the Justice Department, flew  to Teheran over the weekend to participate in a conference on Iranian grievances against the United States.         The group, which included Ramsey Clark, the former At...
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of 10 Americans, ignoring warnings from the Justice Department, flew to Teheran over the weekend to participate in a conference on Iranian grievances against the United States. The group, which included Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, made the trip despite the Administration's ban on travel by Americans to Iran and against the advice of the State Department, which said it feared the Americans' presence would be used for propaganda purposes.

headline.main: 10 AMERICANS FLY TO IRAN PARLEY IN DEFIANCE OF CARTER TRAVEL BAN
